summary: This document is the Last Will and Testament of Jeffrey E. Epstein, outlining the distribution of his estate, the appointment of executors, and the powers granted to them. It includes provisions for the payment of debts, taxes, and the management of his estate's assets. A codicil dated June 6, 2013, is also included, which modifies the appointment of a successor executor.

persons.name: Jeffrey E. Epstein
persons.context: Jeffrey E. Epstein is the individual making the will, detailing the distribution of his estate and appointing executors.

persons.name: Darren K. Indyke

persons.context: Andrew Farkas is appointed as a successor executor in the event that one of the primary executors fails to qualify or ceases to act.

persons.name: David J. Mitchell
persons.context: David J. Mitchell is appointed as a successor executor in the first codicil to Epstein's will.

persons.name: Richard Kahn
persons.context: Richard Kahn is one of the witnesses who signed the will and the first codicil.

persons.name: Harry I. Reller
persons.context: Harry I. Reller is the notary public who witnessed the signing of the first codicil.

events.title: Execution of Last Will and Testament
events.description: Jeffrey E. Epstein executed his Last Will and Testament, outlining the distribution of his estate and appointing executors.

events.title: Execution of First Codicil
events.description: Jeffrey E. Epstein executed a first codicil to his Last Will and Testament, modifying the appointment of a successor executor.

locations: Little St. James Island, St. Thomas, United States Virgin Islands
keyFacts: Jeffrey E. Epstein's Last Will and Testament was executed on October 24, 2012.
Darren K. Indyke, Joseph Pagano, and James E. Staley were appointed as executors of Epstein's estate.
David J. Mitchell was appointed as a successor executor in the first codicil dated June 6, 2013.
The will includes provisions for the payment of debts, taxes, and management of estate assets.
The document was witnessed and notarized, confirming its validity.
